metadata.title: Design, synthesis and characterization of doped-titanium oxide nanomaterials with environmental and angiogenic applications

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Science of the Total Environment
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /sc i totenv
Design, synthesis and characterization of doped-titanium oxide nanomaterials with environmental and angiogenic applications
Susheel Kumar Nethi a,1, Neeraja Aparna Anand P. a, Beatriz Rico-Oller b, Antonio Rodríguez-Diéguez c, Santiago Gómez-Ruiz b,⁎, Chitta Ranjan Patra a,⁎⁎,1 a Department of Chemical Biology, CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Uppal Road, Tarnaka, Hyderabad 500007, Telangana State, India b Departamento de Biología y Geología, Física y Química Inorgánica, ESCET, Universidad Rey Juan Carlos, Calle Tulipán s/n, 28933 Móstoles, Spain c Departamento de Química Inorgánica, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de Granada, Avda Fuentenueva s/n, 18071 Granada, Spain
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• Zinc-doped titania-based nanoparticles have been synthesized and characterized • The synthesized nanosystems have a potential application in water decontamination • Some Zn-doped titania-based nanomaterials have shown improved proangiogenic properties in vitro. • Nanomaterials have shown an interesting potential for the in vivo formation of new blood vessels in chick embryo model
⁎ Correspondence to: S. Gómez-Ruiz, COMET-NANO Gr 28933 Móstoles, Spain. ⁎⁎ Correspondence to: C. R. Patra, Department of Chemi
E-mail addresses: santiago.gomez@urjc.es (S. Gómez-R 1 Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.05.005 0048-9697/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Design and development of Zn-doped TiO2 nanostructures for multifunctional environmental (water remediation) and pro-angiogenic applications.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 2 March 2017 Received in revised form 30 April 2017 Accepted 1 May 2017 Available online xxxx
Since the last decade, the metal composite nanostructures have evolved as promising candidates in regard to their wide applications in the fields of science and engineering. Recently, several investigators identified the titanium based nanomaterials as excellent agents formultifunctional environmental and biomedical applications. In this perspective, we have developed a series of zinc-doped (2 and 5%) titanium oxide-based nanomaterials using various reaction conditions and calcination temperatures (TZ1–TZ3: calcined at 500 °C, TZ4–TZ6: calcined at 600 °C and TZ7–TZ9: calcined at 700 °C). The calcined materials (TZ1 to TZ9) were thoroughly analyzed by several physico-chemical characterizationmethods. The increase of the calcination temperature results in significant changes of the textural properties of the nanostructured materials. In addition, the increase of the calcination temperature leads to the formation of anatase/rutile mixtures with higher quantity of rutile. Furthermore, incorporation of zinc changes the morphology of the obtained nanoparticles. The materials were studied in the photodegradation of methylene blue observing that materials calcined at lower temperatures (TZ1–TZ3) have higher photocatalytic activity than those of the materials calcined at 600 °C (TZ4–TZ6), rutile-based systems TZ7–TZ9 are not active. Based on the background literature of titanium and zinc based nanostructures in therapeutic angiogenesis, we have explored the pro-angiogenic properties of thesematerials using various in vitro and Keywords: Doped-titanium oxide Zinc Photodegradation Angiogenesis Chorioallantoic membrane
oup, Departamento de Biología y Geología, Física y Química Inorgánica, ESCET, Universidad Rey Juan Carlos, Calle Tulipán s/n,
cal Biology, CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Uppal Road, Tarnaka, Hyderabad - 500007, Telangana State, India. uiz), crpatra@iict.res.in, patra.chitta@gmail.com (C.R. Patra). ), Taramani, Chennai, India.
in vivo assays. The zinc-doped titanium dioxide nanostructures (TZ5 and TZ6) exhibited increased cell viability, proliferation, enhanced S-phase cell population, increased pro-angiogenic messengers (ROS: reactive oxygen species and NO: nitric oxide) production and promoted in vivo blood vessel formation in a plausible mechanistic p38/STAT3 dependent signaling cascade. Altogether, the results of the present study showcase these zinc dopedtitanium oxide nanoparticles as promising candidates for environmental (water-remediation) and therapeutic angiogenic applications.
© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Titanium dioxide (TiO2) has gained immense importance owing to its wide applications in various fields such as cosmetics, paints, food and healthcare sectors (Chen and Mao, 2007). The initial discovery of the photocatalytic splitting of water exhibited by TiO2 (Fujishima and Honda, 1972) has promoted its extensive applications in photocatalysis, photovoltaic and solar cells and hydrogen production (Ding andNagpal, 2016; Feng et al., 2012; Rico-Oller et al., 2016). Recently, several research groups started working on the design, development and multifunctional applications of TiO2-based nanomaterials (Chen and Mao, 2007; Giovannetti et al., 2015; Lázaro-Navas et al., 2015; Marelli et al., 2016; Nair and Elizabeth, 2015). The TiO2 based nanostructures have been studied in several areas of environmental and biomedical applications attributed to their unique physico-chemical characteristics, catalytic efficiency, photochemical stability and biocompatibility properties (Bai and Zhou, 2014; Brammer et al., 2012; Venkatasubbu et al., 2013). For example, titanium oxide is one of the most important compounds used for advanced oxidation processes such as heterogeneous photocatalytic degradation of pollutants, which can be applied in water remediation. In this context, organic dyes like rhodamine-B or methylene blue (MB) are clear objectives for this kind of processes and the scientific community is always in search of novel nanostructured titanium oxide-based systems due to their low price and stability (Chong et al., 2010; Mahlambi et al., 2015; Tsydenova et al., 2015). Furthermore, in the last decade TiO2 nanoparticles have emerged as potent candidates for various biomedical applications such as bone growth and regeneration (Brammer et al., 2012; Raines et al., 2010), drug delivery (Venkatasubbu et al., 2013), bio-medical devices (Kulkarni et al., 2015), biosensors (Bai and Zhou, 2014; Bao et al., 2008), vascular implants (Park et al., 2009) etc. Over the recent years many research groups have carried out the doping of various metallic ions into the lattice of TiO2 andwidely investigated their environmental and biomedical applications.
In this context, earlier reports suggest that the incorporation of metals ions especially Zn2+ have significantly enhanced the photocatalytic activity in water remediation (Rico-Oller et al., 2016; Sánchez-Muñoz et al., 2013) and the photoelectric and photovoltaic properties of TiO2 for solar cell applications (Zhu et al., 2010). On the other hand, Zn-doped titania nanostructures have been well studied for various biomedical applications as zinc is an essential element required for physiological growth, metabolism, neurological development, immunity etc. (Frassinetti et al., 2006). Recent reports demonstrated the anti-bacterial properties of the Zn-doped titania nanostructures against various Gram positive and Gramnegative bacterial strains (Amna et al., 2012; Arunachalam et al., 2015). Another study demonstrated the osteogenic, bone growth and regeneration properties of Zn-incorporated TiO2 coatings in animal model (Qiao et al., 2014). Very recently, the role of TiO2 based nanostructures in modulating the angiogenesis process is being well-investigated (Beltran-Partida et al., 2017; Gong et al., 2017; Jo et al., 2014; Raines et al., 2010). Angiogenesis, the development of newer blood vessels from existing vasculature, plays major role in the embryonic growth, development and several other important patho-physiological processes (Carmeliet and Jain, 2011). Our group including others have thoroughly demonstrated the
pro-angiogenic properties of zinc oxide nanoparticles in various cellular and animal model systems (Augustine et al., 2014; Barui et al., 2012).
In this context, the present study was aimed at incorporation of zinc into the TiO2 nanostructural network and evaluating their photocatalytic and pro-angiogenic responses. The influence of these nanomaterials on both the environmental (photocatalysis: MB degradation) as well as the pro-angiogenic responses in endothelial cells (HUVECs and EA.hy926 cells) was performed employing several in vitro [cell viability, cell cycle, ROS (DCFDA), NO (Griess) estimation and immunoblot] and in vivo angiogenesis assays [chick chorioallantoic membrane (CAM)]. Henceforth, from the observations of the present study, we strongly believe that the Zn-doped titania nanostructures could be developed as potential candidates for environmental and pro-angiogenic applications.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Titanium(IV) isopropoxide - 97%, succinic acid - 99.7%, 2-propanol - 99%, MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), RIPA, PIC (protease inhibitor cocktail), DCFDA (2′,7′-dichlorofluorescein diacetate) and propidium iodide (PI) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, USA and used without any further purification. Nitric acid and zinc nitrate hexahydrate - 98% were procured from Fluka Analytical and Acros-Organics, respectively. Methylene blue (MB) purchased from Scharlau, was chosen as a model pollutant for testing photocatalytic activities of the synthesized materials. Milli-Q water (18.2 MV cm, Millipore Waters, USA) was used in all the syntheses. The primary phospho-STAT3 and STAT3 antibodies were procured from Cell Signaling Technologies and the secondary anti-rabbit IgG horse radish peroxidase (HRP) antibody was purchased from Thermo Pierce. The Nitrocellulose/PVDF membrane and the super signal west picochemiluminescent substrate were procured from Thermo Scientific, USA.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of TiO2 and TiO2-Zn-based materials
sections.text:
TiO2 and TiO2-Zn-basedmaterials were prepared using a slightmodification of the synthetic method previously described by our group (Rico-Oller et al., 2016; Sánchez-Muñoz et al., 2013). The hydrolysis of titanium(IV) isopropoxide is carried out in Milli-Q water at a controlled pH of 2.2 which is achieved by adding succinic acid. The Zn-doping quantity is controlled by adding different amounts of zinc nitrate. In addition, the crystallization of the titanium oxide materials in form of either anatase-based or rutile-based nanostructured systems is controlled by using different calcination temperatures.
In brief, for a regular synthesis, a 100mL solution containing the desiredmolar amount of zinc nitrate hexahydrate was prepared inMilli-Q water. Subsequently, a 100 mL aliquot of a titanium(IV) isopropoxide solution in dry 2-propanol (prepared immediately before addition, in order to avoid uncontrolled hydrolysis) is prepared. Both solutions were added dropwise (1 mL/min) to 500 mL of the acidic solution using a peristaltic pump Perimax 12/4. The pH of the acidic solution was previously adjusted to pH 2.2 using succinic acid.
After the slow addition of the solutions of titanium(IV) isopropoxide and zinc nitrate, the suspension was stirred at room temperature for 16 h at 1500 rpm. The mixture was then filtered and the resulting solid was dried at 90 °C for 6 h. The resulting solid was ground in a mortar and subsequently calcined in a muffle Carbolite AAF 1100 under static conditions at 500 °C, 600 °Cor 700 °C for 16 hwith a heating rate of 1.0 °C/min from room temperature to the target calcination temperature.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization of TiO2 and TiO2-Zn-based materials
sections.text: The synthesizedmaterials were characterized by different analytical techniques in order to determine the physical and chemical properties of materials.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. N2 gas adsorption–desorption
sections.text: Isotherms were obtained at 77 K using a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 porosimeter. The sampleswere outgassed in an inert atmosphere before analysis and the total pore volume was assumed as the one recorded at P/P0 = 0.97. Surface specific areas were calculated using the BET method. Pore size distributions were determined by the BJH.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Powder X-ray diffraction
sections.text: XRD pattern of the materials were obtained on a Philips PW3040/00 X'Pert MPD/MRD at 40 mA and 45 kV, using a wavelength Cu Kα (λ = 1.54 Å). The mean crystallite size (D) was calculated from the line broadening of corresponding X-ray diffraction peaks, according to the Scherrer equation (Danilchenko et al., 2002; Reyes-Coronado et al., 2008). All diffractograms of titanium oxide-based materials are close to the Cauchy function (Klug and Alexander, 1975).

sections.heading: 2.3.3. X-ray fluorescence
sections.text: Zn-doping (wt%) determination by XRF was carried out with an Xrayfluorescence spectrophotometer Phillips MagiXwith anX-ray source of 1 kWand an Rh anode using a helium atmosphere. The quantification method is able to analyze from 0.0001% to 100% Zn.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. DR-UV–vis spectroscopy
sections.text: All spectra were recorded with a Varian Cary 500 Scan using solid samples in diffuse reflectance mode and transformed to a magnitude proportional to the extinction coefficient (K) by means of the Kubelka–Munk function (F(R)), which was used for the calculation of the band-gap.

sections.heading: 2.3.5. Transmission electron microscopy
sections.text: TEM was carried out with a Philips Tecnai 20, operating at 200 kV, with thermionic gun and LaB6 filament; 2.7 Å resolution and ±70° tilt of the sample.

sections.heading: 2.3.6. Photoluminescence experiments
sections.text: AVarianCary-Eclipsefluorescence spectrofluorometerwas used to obtain the fluorescence spectra of thematerials. The spectrofluorometerwas equipped with a xenon discharge lamp (peak power equivalent to 75 kW), Czerny–Turner monochromators, and a R-928 photomultiplier tubewhich is red sensitive (even 900 nm)withmanual or automatic voltage controlled using Cary Eclipse software forWindows 95/98/NT system. The photomultiplier detector voltage was 700 V and the instrument excitation and emission slits were set at 20 and 10 nm, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.4. Photocatalytic studies of degradation of aqueous solutions ofmethylene blue (MB)
sections.text:
The photocatalytic activity of TiO2 and TiO2-Zn-based materials was determined by a degradation reaction of MB, an organic contaminant which facilitates visualization of the results under visible light. The reactions were carried out using a fixed amount of the TiO2 and TiO2-Zn-
based materials (25 mg) which was dispersed in 50 mL of an aqueous 0.01 mM solution of MB. The mixture of MB solution and the photocatalyst was stirred in the darkness of a black box (Spectronics Cabinet Model CM-10) with a multi-shaker (OVAN) at 320 rpm for 1 h to ensure the MB adsorption equilibrium was reached. Subsequently, the suspensions were irradiated in the black box with a 6 W Hg tube lamp (Spectronics ENF-240C/FE) operating at 365 nm, and the reaction was stirred at 320 rpm at different time intervals (0 min, 30 min 1 h, 2 h and 6 h). After the photocatalytic treatment, the solution was filtered and the absorbance of the solutionmeasured in a spectrophotometer UV–vis Analytik Jena SPECORD 200, at 660 nm (maximum wavelength of MB). The final MB degradation was monitored by measuring the changes of UV–vis absorption spectra as a function of irradiation time. All experiments were carried out in duplicate, and absorbance measurements in triplicate. The reproducibility of results in terms of error was, in all cases, b10%.

sections.heading: 2.5. Cell culture
sections.text: The human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) were purchased from Lonza and cultured in endothelial basal media (EBM-2) supplementedwith 5% fetal bovine serum (FBS), growth factors and antibiotics. The EA.hy926 cells were grown in Dulbecco's modified eagles medium (DMEM) containing 10% FBS and antibiotics. All the cells were grown in humidified incubator (Thermo Fisher Scientific) maintained at 37 °C and 5% CO2. VEGF (40 ng/mL)was used as a positive control in all the biological experiments.

sections.heading: 2.6. MTT assay
sections.text: TheMTT assay was performed as per our previous protocols (Nethi et al., 2014). Briefly, the cells (HUVECs, EA.hy926 and L929) were seeded in 96-well plates following a density of around 8 × 103 cells per well. The cells were grown in starving media (0.2% FBS) overnight before performing the treatments. The cells were then treated with TiO2-Zn nanoparticles (NPs) [TZ1–TZ9] in a dose dependent manner (1–50 μg/ mL) and incubated for a period of 24 h. After the incubation time, the media of cells was replaced with 0.5 mg/mL MTT prepared in media and incubated for 3 h. Later, theMTT solutionwas removed andDMSO:Methanol (1:1 v/v) was added to the cells to dissolve the insoluble formazan crystals. The absorbance of the samples was measured at 570 nm using a Synergy H1X multimode plate reader. All the treatments were performed in triplicates and normalized with the untreated controls.

sections.heading: 2.7. Cell cycle analysis
sections.text: Briefly, the HUVECs were cultured and grown to confluence. Further the cells were starved (0.2% FBS) for overnight prior to treatments. The cells were then incubated with TiO2-Zn (TZ5 and TZ6) NPs (10 μg/mL) for 24 h. After the incubation period, the cells were collected by trypsinization and washed with 1 × PBS (phosphate buffer saline) by centrifugation and fixed in 70% ethanol for overnight. Further, after the fixation time, the cells were washed and stainedwith propidium iodide (PI) stain supplementedwith RNase and triton-X for 40min in dark at room temperature. The unbound PI stain was removed by washing cells with PBS and the cell cycle analysis was performed by flow cytometry using BD FACS canto.

sections.heading: 2.8. Detection of cellular reactive oxygen species (ROS)
sections.text:
In brief, the endothelial cells (EA.hy926) were grown and seeded into 6-well plates at around 5 × 106 cells per well. After confluent growth, the cells were serum starved for overnight preceding the treatments. Further, cells were incubated with TiO2-Zn (TZ5 and TZ6) NPs (10 μg/mL) for a time period of 24 h. The cells were then washed twice with 1× PBS and incubated for 30 min with DCFDA (30 μM).
Later the unbound excess DCFDA was removed with PBS washing and cells were lysed using cell lysis (RIPA) buffer. Then the cell lysate was centrifuged and the fluorescence of the resultant sample supernatants was measured at an excitation and emission maximum wavelength of 480 nm and 530 nm, respectively using a synergy H1X multimode plate reader.

sections.heading: 2.9. Determination of cellular total nitric oxide (NO)
sections.text: The EA.hy926 cells were cultured and seeded in 96-well plates and cultured till they reach confluent growth. Before performing the treatments, the cells were serum starved (0.2% FBS) for 12 h. Further, the cells were treated with TiO2-Zn (TZ5) NPs (10 μg/mL) for different time periods of 0–24 h. The supernatant media of the treated cells was collected, transferred to a 96-well plate and the total NO levels were determined employing the NO detection kit (Arbor assay kit, MI, USA) following our previously reported protocols (Adela et al., 2015).

sections.heading: 2.10. Chick embryo angiogenesis (CEA) assay
sections.text: The fertile hatching eggs laid by the Vanaraja strain chicken variety were purchased from the Directorate of Poultry Research (ICAR), Hyderabad and incubated in egg incubators (Southern) at 37 °C and 50– 60% relative humidity. On the fourth day of incubation, the eggs were peeled on the top thusmaking awindow for performing the treatments. Further, the eggs were incubated with TiO2-Zn (TZ5 and TZ6) NPs (10 μg/mL) and the images of the chick embryo vasculature were captured at 0 h and 4 h post treatments using a stereo microscope fitted with a camera (Leica). The effect of the treatments on the development of vasculature was quantified using the AngioQuant software.

sections.heading: 2.11. Western blotting
sections.text: The plausible pro-angiogenesis signaling mechanism of TiO2-Zn (TZ5) NPs in endothelial cells was determined usingWestern blot technique following our previous reports (Nethi et al., 2015). The serum starved EA.hy926 cells were treated with TiO2-Zn (TZ5) NPs (10 μg/ mL) and incubated for 60 min. Further, the cells were lysed using RIPA + PIC (protease inhibitor cocktail) and the lysate was centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 15min at 4 °C. The resultant supernatant was collected and the estimation of protein concentrationwas done using Bradford assay. An equal concentration (50 μg) of proteinswere run and separated on a SDS-PAGE and transferred to a PVDFmembrane. Themembrane was incubated with 5% milk in TBS-T (tris buffered saline- 0.1% tween20) solution for 2 h at room temperature (RT) on gel rocker (Genei, SLM-GR 100) to block the non-specific interaction. The membrane was then added with the primary antibodies [Phospho-p38 MAPK (Thr180/Tyr182), p38 MAPK, Phospho-STAT3 (Tyr705) and STAT3] diluted in TBS-T for overnight on rocker at 4 °C. After incubation, the membranewaswashedwith TBS-T thrice and anti-rabbit IgG secondary antibody was added to it and kept on rocker for 2 h at room temperature. Finally, the blot was washed with TBS-T and developed using colorimetric (p38 MAPK) or chemiluminescence (STAT3) methods.

sections.heading: 3.1. Synthesis and characterization of TiO2 and TiO2-Zn-based materials
3.1.1. Synthesis of TiO2 and TiO2-Zn-based materials
sections.text:
TiO2 and TiO2-Zn-based nanomaterials were prepared by a slight modification of a simple method described previously by us (Rico-Oller et al., 2016; Sánchez-Muñoz et al., 2013). This method consists of a controlled hydrolysis of titanium(IV) isopropoxide in a solution of succinic acid inwater at a controlled pHof 2.2, in addition, zinc nitrate is also added dropwise to the mixture. After 16 h of reactions the solids were filtered and washed with water and a final calcination step was
carried out at 500, 600 or 700 °C. Using this synthetic pathway we synthesized nine different TiO2 or TiO2-Zn-based materials (TZ1 to TZ9, Table 1). Materials TZ1–TZ3 consist of those calcined at 500 °C, while TZ4–TZ6 were calcined at 600 °C and TZ7–TZ9 at 700 °C.
The resulting nanostructured titania-based materials were characterized by different techniques such as N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, powder X-ray diffraction, diffuse reflectance UV spectroscopy, transmission electronic microscopy (TEM) and photoluminescence.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Characterization by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms
sections.text:
Characterization by nitrogen adsorption desorption shows that the materials calcined at 500 and 600 °C (TZ1–TZ6) give type IV isotherms with hysteresis loop type H2 according to the IUPAC classification (Sing et al., 2008). These isotherms (Fig. 1) are indicative of the formation of porous agglomerations of nanoparticles as it is normally observed in anatase-based systems (Lázaro-Navas et al., 2015; Rico-Oller et al., 2016). In general, there is not a remarkable difference between the forms of the isotherms of the non-doped titanium oxide materials with those of the Zn-dopedmaterials. Only slight variations in the region of relative pressures between 0.6 and 0.8 were observed. However, the BET surface area of thematerials is decreasing when increasing the calcination temperature, thusmaterials TZ1–TZ3 (calcined at 500 °C) have external surface areas between 65 and 82 m2/g while the materials TZ4–TZ6 (calcined at 600 °C) showed external surface areas of between 15 and 33 m2/g (Table 2). Nevertheless, characterization by nitrogen adsorption desorption of the materials calcined at 700 °C (TZ7–TZ9) showed that they are not porous (type III isotherm, Fig. 1), giving BET surface areas of ca. 2m2/g or even lower (Table 2). The almost inexistent porosity of the systems TZ7–TZ9 suggested that titanium oxide is principally in form of rutile.
In the case of the porous systems TZ1–TZ6, the pore size distribution is narrow in the case of thematerials calcined at 500 °C, while this is not homogeneous and much broader in the case of materials calcined at 600 °C (TZ4–TZ6). The distribution is even broader when the materials
calcined at 700 °C are analyzed (for a comparison of materials TZ1, TZ4 and TZ7 pore size distribution see Fig. S1 of Supplementary material). Non-homogeneous distribution of the pores for materials calcined at temperatures higher than 500 °Cwere already observed in other studies
Fig. 2. X-raydiffractionpatterns:MaterialsTZ1–TZ3 show that they are formedmainly by anat by rutile and a small quantity of anatase.
and are associated with phase transitions from anatase to rutile (Sreethawonga et al., 2007).
Therefore, an increase in the calcination temperature decreases the surface area of the material and makes less homogeneous the distribution of the pore size of the aggregates of nanoparticles. In addition, Zn incorporation slightly increases surface area and pore volume, keeping practically constant the pore size.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. X-ray fluorescence
sections.text: To determine the quantity of Zn that has been incorporated in the structure of the titanium oxide NPs, all materials have been characterized by XRF. Thus, for materials which were obtained starting form a theoretical amount of 2% of Zn (TZ2, TZ5 and TZ7) the amount of Zn found was, in all cases, close to 1.4%, observing an incorporation of 70% of Zn. However, in the case of the nanostructured materials obtained starting form a theoretical amount of 5% of Zn (TZ3, TZ6 and TZ9) the incorporation rate is lower for TZ3 and TZ6 (60%) which showed a Zn amount of ca. 3.0%, while in the case of TZ9, almost all the added Zn was incorporated in the structure showing a Zn% wt of 4.7% (Table 2).

sections.heading: 3.1.4. Powder X-ray diffraction
sections.text:
All materials were characterized by powder XRD observing that they are all crystalline systems. The diffractograms showed the peaks corresponding to the anatase phase or rutile depending on calcination
ase, TZ4–TZ6 are formedby amixture of anatase and rutile and TZ7–TZ9 are formedmainly
temperature and incorporation of Zn (Fig. 2). The anatase (JCPDS pattern reference card No. 21-1272 (Reyes-Coronado et al., 2008) or 84-1286) give the peaks assigned to an octahedral system with 2θ values of ca. 25° (101), 48° (200) and 63° (116) while rutile (JCPDS No. 21–1276 or 88- 1175) (Reyes-Coronado et al., 2008) usually shows diffraction peaks corresponding with a tetragonal system at 2θ values of 27° (110) 36° (101) 55° (211). For TZ1–TZ9, no brookite peaks were observed as it previously happened for other Zn-doped titania-based systems which were synthesized using other acids for the preparation of the aqueous solution at pH of ca. 2 (Rico-Oller et al., 2016; Sánchez-Muñoz et al., 2013). It seems that the use of succinic acid stabilizes titanium containing succinate intermediates, which are being hydrolyzed to titanium oxide in a more controlled way to give anatase. On the other hand, as observed in previous experiments using Zn-doped titanium oxide NPs (Rico-Oller et al., 2016; Sánchez-Muñoz et al., 2013), doping with zinc is associated with a slight decrease of crystallinity (Fig. 2).
In addition, in all cases, for the samples calcined at 500 °C (TZ1–TZ3) anatase is the only crystalline component of themixture, while for samples calcined at 600 °C (TZ4–TZ6), anatase is the principal component of the material (82–96%) and only low amounts of rutile were observed (Table 2). However, for samples calcined at 700 °C, themain component of the nanostructured material is rutile with a percentage higher than 90% of the mixture.
According to the calculated crystallite size of all the synthesized materials, one can see a decrease of the size when increasing the calcination temperature from 500 °C (TZ1–TZ3) to 600 °C (TZ4–TZ6) with no significant changes promoted by Zn doping (Table 2). However, for materials calcined at 700 °C and composed principally by rutile (TZ7–TZ9) the crystallite size is much higher due to the larger amount of rutile. Bearing in mind the crystallite size of materials calcined at 700 °C, it
seems that the highest zinc doping promotes a slight decrease of the crystallite size.

sections.heading: 3.1.5. Transmission electron microscopy
sections.text:
TEM images (Fig. 3) confirm the formation of agglomerates of titanium oxide NPs with different morphologies and particle size. In general, on raising the calcination temperature, the particle size increases, as the phase transition from anatase to rutile is always associated with an enlargement of the particle size. Thus, materials calcined at 500 °C have particle sizes of between ca. 10–20 nm (TZ1–TZ3, Fig. 3a–c), while materials calcined at 600 °C (TZ4–TZ6, Fig. 3d–f) have higher particle sizes from ca. 20–50 nm, indicating that in the calcination process, the transition from anatase to rutile increased the particle size of the nanostructured materials. In addition, materials calcined a 700 °C (TZ7–TZ9) and composed principally of rutile as confirmed by XRD, have much larger particle sizes of above 50 nm (Fig. 3g–i).
Interestingly, and specially formaterials calcined at 700 °C, the shape of the nanoparticles changes with Zn-doping going from “quasi-spherical” or “squircle” morphologies (Fig. 4a) for non-doped titanium oxide materials (TZ7) to quasi-hexagonal or hexagonal morphologies (Fig. 4b and c) when doped with low quantity of Zn (TZ8 and TZ9). This hexagonalization of thematerials is probably due to the incorporation of Zn and formation of ZnO, as this compound usually forms hexagonal nanoparticles (Lee et al., 2009; Li et al., 2004).

sections.heading: 3.1.6. Diffuse reflectance UV visible spectroscopy
sections.text:
Finally, all materials were characterized by diffuse reflectance UV visible spectroscopy observing that the maximum absorbance of the Kubelka-Munk function of materials calcined at 500 °C (TZ1–TZ3) keeps almost constant after doping. However, the increase of the
4, e) TZ5, f) TZ6, g) TZ7, h) TZ8 and i) TZ9.
temperature of calcination to 600 °C (TZ4–TZ6) shifts themaximum absorbance to slightly higher wavelengths because of the presence of low quantities of rutile. The shift of the maximum absorbance of the
Kubelka-Munk function is even higher in materials calcined at 700 °C (TZ7–TZ9) as these materials mainly contain rutile which usually absorbs at higher wavelengths (for the example of materials TZ1–TZ3 see Fig. 5a–c).
Bearing in mind that all the materials of the series (TZ1–TZ9) are consistent with indirect allowed transition, modified Kubelka-Munk functionswere plotted against the radiation energy to graphically calculate the band-gap (for the example of materials TZ1–TZ3 see Fig. 5d–f). The band gap data (Table 2) show that the values for materials calcined at 500 °C are very similar and have a value of ca. 3.0 eV. However, materials calcined at 600 °C (TZ4–TZ6) showed lower band gap values of ca 2.9 eV, while materials calcined at 700 °C (TZ7–TZ9) have the lowest band gap values of the analyzed materials of ca. 2.7 eV as corresponds to rutile-based nanostructured materials.

sections.heading: 3.2. Environmental applications
sections.text: An interesting property of titanium oxide-based nanomaterials is their photocatalytic activity which can be used for studying the degradation reaction of aqueous solutions of methylene blue as a model for evaluating their potential use in water remediation.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Methylene blue (MB) degradation
sections.text:
The MB degradation reactions were carried out under UV light (365 nm) and regardless of the material used, the degradation experiments showed a high decrease of the MB concentration over time for materials calcined at both 500 or 600 °C (TZ1–TZ6, see Fig. S2 of Supplementary material). However, in case of materials calcined at 700 °C and which are mainly composed by rutile, almost no degradation was observed after 2 h, indicating their very low photocatalytic activity. In general, doping with Zn leads to faster MB degradation kinetic, however, it is important to note that a high doping value (5% Zn) does not have so positive effect in the degradation kinetic when compared with Zn doping at 2%.
spectrum of materials TZ1–TZ3 and d–f) band gap calculations for materials TZ1–TZ3.
For materials with photocatalytic activity (TZ1–TZ6) the MB degradation apparent rate constant (k, s−1) was determined from the regression curves of ln(C/C0) versus irradiation time (see Fig. S3 of Supplementary material), linearly adjusting to pseudo first order kinetics. The results are given in Table 3. For the degradation experiments, the higher the constant, the greater is the methylene blue degradation, which is usually associated with a higher photocatalytic activity in degradation reactions. The results showed apparent constants which were between ca. 3·10−6 and 7·10−5 s−1 and are in good agreement with similar materials reported recently (Rico-Oller et al., 2016) although
Fig. 7. Cell viability assay: The effect of TiO2-Zn (TZ5) NPs (1–50 μg/mL) on the growth and vi dependent fashion.
somewhat lower than those of fluorine-doped titanium oxide materials which are much higher due to the formation of ultra-reactive facets of anatase (Lázaro-Navas et al., 2015). In general, as commented previously, higher rate constantswere observed for Zn dopedmaterials TZ2, TZ3, TZ5 or TZ6 on direct comparison with their corresponding non-doped analogue TZ1 or TZ4. The higher photocatalytic properties of the zincdoped systems may be attributed to a better photogenerated carrier separation efficiency in Zn-doped titanium oxide. Thus, the photoluminescence of the materials TZ1–TZ6 has been measured after an excitation of 365 nm (the wavelength of the photocatalytic experiments) (Fig. S4 and Fig. S5 of Supplementary information). The obtained spectra showed that, for the anatase-based materials (TZ1–TZ6) the doping with Zn slightly displaces the maximum of emission of the materials to higher wavelengths. In addition, an increase of the intensity was also observed for Zn-doped materials (TZ2, TZ3, TZ5 and TZ6) when compared to non-doped titanium oxides (TZ1 and TZ4). Thus, these experiments are confirming the incorporation of Zn in the composite may favor the separation of the photoinduced carriers during the photocatalytic reactions, inducing a higher photocatalytic activity (see Fig. S4 and S5 of Supplementary material).

sections.heading: 3.3.1. TiO2-Zn-based nanomaterials enhance endothelial cell proliferation
sections.text: The effect of TiO2-Zn-based NPs (TZ1–TZ9) on the cellular viability of endothelial cells (HUVECs) was determined usingMTT assay. The results of the assay as shown in Fig. 6 and Fig. S6 demonstrate the enhanced cell viability and proliferation of HUVECs incubated with TiO2Zn-based materials such as TZ5 and TZ6 in a dose-dependent manner. These preliminary observations of enhanced cell viability and proliferation of endothelial cells by these NPs support their pro-angiogenic nature. Further, similar observations were found in EA.hy926 cells incubated with the TZ5 NPs (Fig. 7), which strengthen the above observations. The MTT assay done in the L929 (mouse fibrosarcoma) cells (Fig. 7) showed the biocompatible and non-toxic nature of the TZ5 NPs to fibroblast cells. Taken together, the above results suggest the pro-angiogenic nature of the TiO2-Zn-based materials (TZ5).

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Biocompatible nature of TiO2-Zn-based NPs
sections.text:
The cell cycle analysis was performed to identify the effect of TiO2Zn-basedNPs (TZ5 and TZ6) on the various cell cycle phases. The results of the assay are revealed in Fig. 8 which illustrates that these NPs do not arrest or alter the HUVECs cell cycle, evident from the similar cell population (non-significant difference) at various cell cycle checkpoints of G0/G1, S, and G2/M when compared with untreated cells. These observations suggest the bio-compatible and non-cytotoxic nature of the TiO2-Zn-based NPs in endothelial cells. An increase in the S-phase
ability of EA.hy926 and L929 fibroblast cells was determined using MTT reagent in a dose-
population of the TZ5 treated cells compared to the untreated HUVECs, suggests their pro-angiogenic nature.

sections.heading: 3.3.3. ROS generation by TiO2-Zn-based NPs in endothelial cells
sections.text: It is well-known that the ROS (especially H2O2) regulate several cell signaling pathways and act asmediators to switch the physiological angiogenesis signaling pathways (Kim and Byzova, 2014; Patra et al., 2011). The fluorescence spectroscopy (DCFDA)was employed to determine the role of ROS like or amongothers H2O2 in EA.hy926 cells treated with TiO2-Zn NPs (TZ5 and TZ6). The results of the assay depicted in Fig. 9 demonstrate the enhanced ROS in EA.hy926 cells treated with TZ5 and TZ6 NPs compared to untreated cells. These observations emphasize the profound impact of ROS (H2O2) in TiO2-Zn (TZ5 and TZ6) induced pro-angiogenesis.

sections.heading: 3.3.4. TiO2-Zn NPs enhance cellular NO production
sections.text: The NO is a gaseous lowmolecular weight signalingmolecule which regulates physiological angiogenesis (Sharifpanah et al., 2016). Previous reports illustrate that the ROS (especially hydrogen peroxide: H2O2) act downstream by activating eNOS (endothelial nitric oxide synthase) and induce the formation of NO, awell-established pro-angiogenic signaling molecule (Nethi et al., 2015; Sharifpanah et al., 2016). In this context, the measurement of NO induced in EA.hy926 cells by TZ5 treatment was done to study the impact of NO in the pro-angiogenesis exhibited by TZ5nanoparticles in a time-dependentmanner (0–24 h). The primary results portrayed TZ5 as the active compound, which encouraged us to investigate the role of NO in TZ5 induced angiogenesis. The assay results as shown in Fig. 10 indicate the enhanced NO in endothelial cells incubated with TZ5 NPs with high NO level at 4 h post-treatment compared to untreated cells. Altogether, these observations signify the effect of NO in TiO2-Zn nanostructures triggered angiogenesis.

sections.heading: 3.3.5. In vivo angiogenesis induced by TiO2-Zn NPs
sections.text: The in vivo angiogenesis exhibited by the TiO2-ZnNPs (TZ5 and TZ6) wasmonitored using the chick CEA assay, which is a standardmodel for determining the in vivo growth and development of new blood vessels (Nethi et al., 2015). The images of the eggs incubated with the TiO2-Zn (TZ5 and TZ6) NPs are shown in Fig. 11a–d, which clearly exhibit the increased growth of new blood vessels (angiogenesis) in eggs incubated with TiO2-Zn NPs. The quantification of the images carried out using the AngioQuant software exhibits the increase in length, size and junction parameters of blood vessels growth and development which confirm the above observations (Fig. 11e–g). Taken together, the above results confirm the ability of TiO2-Zn (TZ5 and TZ6) NPs to induce angiogenesis in vivo.

sections.heading: 3.3.6. Plausible pro-angiogenesis signaling of TiO2-Zn NPs
sections.text:
The VEGF is a well-established endogenous growth factor which is reported to trigger downstream angiogenesis by regulating several cell signaling pathways, including the p38 MAPK/STAT3 signaling cascade (Hoeben et al., 2004; Makhoul et al., 2016). As per the preliminary observations obtained from the above in vitro and in vivo experiments
(Sections 3.3.1–3.3.5), the TZ5NPs found as themost suitable candidate nanomaterial was chosen for themolecularmechanistic study. Themolecular mechanisms underlying the pro-angiogenic signaling exhibited by TZ5 NPs was investigated using Western blot. The results of the assay (Fig. 12a, c) signify the increased phosphorylation of p38 MAPK at Thr180/Tyr182 residue and STAT3 at Tyr705 residue in EA.hy926 cells treated with TiO2-Zn NPs in comparison with untreated control cells. The Fig. 12b, d shows the densitometric analysis of the protein bands expression (performed using the ImageJ software) supporting, therefore, the above observations. Henceforth, the above results suggest that the TiO2-Zn NPs induced pro-angiogenesis is mediated through p38MAPK/STAT3 signaling cascade, which is in agreement with the reported literature of growth factor induced angiogenesis.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The present study has demonstrated that nanostructured systems based on Zn-doped titanium oxide in form of anatase or mixtures anatase/rutilemay be useful in the photodegradation of organic dyes ofwaters and that are excellent pro-angiogenic agents. The preparation of the nanostructured systems is carried out using a simple and cheapmethod by the hydrolysis of titanium(IV) isopropoxide in acidic solutions and doping with different quantities of Zn using simple zinc nitrate as metal source. The reaction conditions and calcination temperature directly influence the composition, textural andmorphological properties of the synthesized materials. The calcined materials tested in the photocatalytic degradation of aqueous solutions of MB showed that the materials calcined at 500 °C and 600 °C gave kinetic constants ofMBdegradation of between ca. 3·10−6 and 7·10−5 s−1 observing a higher activity in Zn-doped materials and a potential application of these systems in visible-light driven photocatalytic degradation of organic dyes after a future incorporation of Pd nanoparticles doping. Further, evaluating the samples for their proangiogenic properties has shown the Zn doped-TiO2 nanostructures calcined at 600 °C, exhibited improved pro-angiogenic properties. Detailed biological evaluation showed that these nanomaterials promoted endothelial cell proliferation, increased S (DNA synthesis)- phase population, induced intracellular ROS and NO generation and triggered formation of new blood vessels in chick embryo model in a p38/STAT3 dependent signaling cascade. Considering the results altogether, the titanium oxide based-zinc doped nanostructures, synthesized at optimum conditions in which their morphological and textural properties can be controlled, might be developed as promising candidates for environmental applications (waste-water treatment/remediation) and as alternate treatment strategies for vascular and ischemic diseases involving therapeutic angiogenesis.
μg/mL) and (d) TZ6NPs (10 μg/mL) treatments on the growth and development of blood ighlighted in circle demonstrate the difference in the new blood vessel growth. The factors nction parameters were quantified using the AngioQuant software.

B.R-O. and S.G-R. are thankful to Ministerio de Economía y Competitividad (Spain) for financial support with CTQ2015-66164-R and to Universidad Rey Juan Carlos-Banco de Santander (Excellence Group QUINANOAP, grant no. 30VCPIGI14). We would also like to thank Steve Oglesbee, TCF, UNC Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center, NC, USA and Suvro Chatterjee, AU-KBC, Chennai, India for giving permission to use and sharing the EA.hy926 cells, respectively.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sections.text: Supplementary data to this article, including pore size distribution of thematerials, kinetic study ofMB photodegradation reactions and determination of the apparent rate constant, photoluminiscence spectra of TZ1-TZ9 and a graph showing the effect of TiO2-Zn (TZ1-TZ9) nanomaterials on the growth and viability of HUVECs, can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.05.005.

referenceMentions.context: The initial discovery of the photocatalytic splitting of water exhibited by TiO2 (Fujishima and Honda, 1972) has promoted its extensive applications in photocatalysis, photovoltaic and solar cells and hydrogen production (Ding andNagpal, 2016; Feng et al.

The initial discovery of the photocatalytic splitting of water exhibited by TiO2 (Fujishima and Honda, 1972) has promoted its extensive applications in photocatalysis, photovoltaic and solar cells and hydrogen production (Ding andNagpal, 2016; Feng et al., 2012; Rico-Oller et al., 2016).

The initial discovery of the photocatalytic splitting of water exhibited by TiO2 (Fujishima and Honda, 1972) has promoted its extensive applications in photocatalysis, photovoltaic and solar cells and hydrogen production (Ding andNagpal, 2016; Feng et al., 2012; Rico-Oller et al., 2016).

Recently, several research groups started working on the design, development and multifunctional applications of TiO2-based nanomaterials (Chen and Mao, 2007; Giovannetti et al., 2015; Lázaro-Navas et al., 2015; Marelli et al., 2016; Nair and Elizabeth, 2015).

The TiO2 based nanostructures have been studied in several areas of environmental and biomedical applications attributed to their unique physico-chemical characteristics, catalytic efficiency, photochemical stability and biocompatibility properties (Bai and Zhou, 2014; Brammer et al., 2012; Venkatasubbu et al., 2013).

The TiO2 based nanostructures have been studied in several areas of environmental and biomedical applications attributed to their unique physico-chemical characteristics, catalytic efficiency, photochemical stability and biocompatibility properties (Bai and Zhou, 2014; Brammer et al., 2012; Venkatasubbu et al., 2013).

In this context, organic dyes like rhodamine-B or methylene blue (MB) are clear objectives for this kind of processes and the scientific community is always in search of novel nanostructured titanium oxide-based systems due to their low price and stability (Chong et al., 2010; Mahlambi et al., 2015; Tsydenova et al., 2015).

In this context, organic dyes like rhodamine-B or methylene blue (MB) are clear objectives for this kind of processes and the scientific community is always in search of novel nanostructured titanium oxide-based systems due to their low price and stability (Chong et al., 2010; Mahlambi et al., 2015; Tsydenova et al., 2015).

Furthermore, in the last decade TiO2 nanoparticles have emerged as potent candidates for various biomedical applications such as bone growth and regeneration (Brammer et al., 2012; Raines et al., 2010), drug delivery (Venkatasubbu et al.
, 2010), drug delivery (Venkatasubbu et al., 2013), bio-medical devices (Kulkarni et al.
, 2015), biosensors (Bai and Zhou, 2014; Bao et al., 2008), vascular implants (Park et al.
, 2015), biosensors (Bai and Zhou, 2014; Bao et al., 2008), vascular implants (Park et al.

In this context, earlier reports suggest that the incorporation of metals ions especially Zn have significantly enhanced the photocatalytic activity in water remediation (Rico-Oller et al., 2016; Sánchez-Muñoz et al., 2013) and the photoelectric and photovoltaic properties of TiO2 for solar cell applications (Zhu et al.

In this context, earlier reports suggest that the incorporation of metals ions especially Zn have significantly enhanced the photocatalytic activity in water remediation (Rico-Oller et al., 2016; Sánchez-Muñoz et al., 2013) and the photoelectric and photovoltaic properties of TiO2 for solar cell applications (Zhu et al.
, 2013) and the photoelectric and photovoltaic properties of TiO2 for solar cell applications (Zhu et al., 2010).

Recent reports demonstrated the anti-bacterial properties of the Zn-doped titania nanostructures against various Gram positive and Gramnegative bacterial strains (Amna et al., 2012; Arunachalam et al., 2015).

Recent reports demonstrated the anti-bacterial properties of the Zn-doped titania nanostructures against various Gram positive and Gramnegative bacterial strains (Amna et al., 2012; Arunachalam et al., 2015).

Very recently, the role of TiO2 based nanostructures in modulating the angiogenesis process is being well-investigated (Beltran-Partida et al., 2017; Gong et al., 2017; Jo et al., 2014; Raines et al., 2010).

Our group including others have thoroughly demonstrated the pro-angiogenic properties of zinc oxide nanoparticles in various cellular and animal model systems (Augustine et al., 2014; Barui et al., 2012).
